channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: The Insurance Industry Is Winning a Fight to Kill New Protections for Retirement Savers
item.description: A Labor Department rule is forecast to curb commissions on annuities sharply. The products are sold as a way to convert retirement savings including an IRA into an often-guaranteed income stream that can carry hefty charges.

item.title: CVS slashes profit outlook on higher medical costs, says top Aetna executive will leave
item.description: CVS said higher medical costs are weighing on its insurance business, and announced Aetna President Brian Kane will step down.

item.title: Big Food Would Benefit from Private Ownership
item.description: Mars’s bid for Kellanova highlights the benefits of being out of public view.

item.title: Disney beats estimates as combined streaming services turn a profit
item.description: Disney beat estimates as its combined streaming businesses — Disney+, Hulu and ESPN+ — turned a profit for the first time.

item.title: Stocks Claw Back Losses After Global Selloff
item.description: The Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq advanced after the Nikkei jumped 10%.

item.title: Novo Nordisk shares dip as Wegovy maker posts earnings miss, cuts operating profit outlook
item.description: Novo Nordisk on Wednesday announced its second quarter earnings for 2024.

item.title: KKR Founders Sued for Allegedly Getting Giant Payday for No Work
item.description: The lawsuit adds to legal scrutiny of arcane tax deals benefiting private-equity heavyweights.

item.title: Sony rules out renewing offer for Paramount, says it wouldn't fit strategy
item.description: Hiroki Totoki, Sony's chief financial officer, said the tech giant has no plans to submit a revised offer for Paramount.

item.title: Why Everyone Needs a 'Digital Death-Cleaning' Plan
item.description: Nobody wants to leave heirs a confusing collection of files they can’t open, accounts they can’t access and assets they can’t locate.

item.title: SoftBank swings back to gains at Vision Fund tech arm, announces up to $3.4 billion share buyback
item.description: SoftBank announced it would buy back up to 6.8% of shares available amounting to up to 500 billion yen ($3.4 billion).
